definition: connected with the scientific study of the physics of the earth, including its atmosphere, climate and magnetism
moving around the earth at the equator at the same speed as the earth turns, so that it appears to be always in the same place in the sky
the art of designing and arranging the steps and movements in dances, especially in ballet; the steps and movements in a particular ballet or show
a unit of computer memory or data, equal to 109, or 1 0003, (= 1 000 000 000) bits
a unit of computer memory or data, equal to 230, or 1 0243, (= 1 073 741 824) bits
connected with plants that have soft stems
a line on a weather map that joins places that have the same air pressure at a particular time
a line on a weather map that joins places that have the same temperature at a particular time
part of a song that is sung after each verse
a piece of music, usually part of a larger work, that is written for a choir (= a group of singers)
a large group of singers
a group of performers who sing and dance in a musical show
the sound of a lot of people expressing approval or disapproval at the same time
a group of performers who comment together on the events of the play
an actor who speaks the opening and closing words of the play
all together
a written record of events in the order in which they happened
a strong feeling of approval of somebody/something because of their good qualities or achievements
polite behaviour towards or care for somebody/something that you think is important
a particular aspect or detail of something
about; relating to
in payment for something
to visit somebody or to send a message of good wishes as a sign of respect for them
used when you are going to disagree, usually quite strongly, with somebody
in connection with
a song for one voice, especially in an opera or oratorio
connected with opera
a cloth bag filled with soft material or feathers that is used, for example, to make a seat more comfortable
a layer of something between two surfaces that keeps them apart
something that protects you against something unpleasant that might happen
the soft inside edge along each side of the table that the balls bounce off
a person who records events in the order in which they happened, in a chronicle
arranged in the order in which they happened
information that describes other information in order to help you understand or use it
a unit for measuring the pressure of the atmosphere. One thousand millibars are equal to one bar.
produced or practised without using artificial chemicals
produced by or from living things
relating to chemical compounds that contain carbon and mainly or ultimately come from living things
connected with the organs of the body
consisting of different parts that are all connected to each other
happening in a slow and natural way, rather than suddenly
to bend with curves rather than being in a straight line
to walk slowly and change direction often, especially without a particular aim
to develop slowly and change subject often, in a way that makes it boring or difficult to understand
the amount of water in the air
conditions in which the air is wet and very warm
made of sand and earth that is left by rivers or floods
the young form of a butterfly while it is changing into an adult inside a hard case, also called a chrysalis
a large, brightly coloured garden flower that is like a ball in shape and is made up of many long narrow petals
the degree to which a material reflects light or radiation
the return and growth of an activity that had stopped
slightly fat in a way that people usually find attractive
